Patient presents with a chief complaint of headache and fatigue. The headache started three days ago and is intermittent, with a severity of 7/10. The patient also reports general fatigue, onset of which is unclear. They are currently taking Ibuprofen 200mg as needed for the headache. They have tried resting and drinking more water, but the headache persists. The patient has a known allergy to Penicillin. Family history is significant for diabetes and heart disease. No other significant family history was reported. The patient denies any recent fevers, chills, or weight loss. Vitals are within normal limits. Further evaluation is ongoing.

Patient presents with a cough that started five days ago. They have been taking cough syrup for it. No known drug allergies. They deny any other symptoms at this time, such as fever, chills, or body aches. Lungs are clear upon auscultation. Throat is slightly red. Patient advised to continue taking cough syrup and to increase fluid intake. Follow up if symptoms worsen or do not improve within the next week.

Patient reports a constant runny nose, which they rate as a 3 out of 10 in severity. They also have a constant sore throat that began two days ago. Occasional sneezing is also present. No medications are currently being taken. The patient has a family history of asthma. No known drug allergies. They deny any fever, cough, or body aches. They are otherwise feeling well and attribute their symptoms to a common cold. They are seeking advice on symptom management.

Patient reports new onset muscle ache today, rating the pain as a 5 out of 10. This is the first occurrence of this symptom. They are currently taking Acetaminophen 500mg every 4 hours. Patient has known allergies to dust mites and pollen. No other symptoms were reported. Vitals are within normal limits. Patient denies any recent illness or injury. They are concerned about the sudden onset of the muscle ache and are seeking advice on how to manage it. Plan is to recommend rest, hydration, and over-the-counter pain relievers as needed. Patient education provided on proper use of Acetaminophen. Follow-up appointment scheduled in one week if symptoms persist.

Patient reports constant back pain for the past 30 days, rated at an 8 out of 10 on a pain scale. They also describe intermittent numbness in their legs for the last 15 days. The patient has been taking Gabapentin 300mg three times daily for the pain. They have a family history of hypertension. No other symptoms were reported. The patient denies any allergies. Their vital signs today are within normal limits: blood pressure 120/80, heart rate 72 bpm, and temperature 98.6Â°F. Lungs are clear to auscultation. A referral to physical therapy has been made and a follow-up appointment scheduled in two weeks.
